Award.AwardTitle: Applications of Equivariant Lifts in Algebraic and Symplectic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a project in symplectic geometry, a branch of pure mathematics. It focuses on Gromov-Witten theory. Gromov-Witten invariants are numbers that appropriately count curves in spaces satisfying certain conditions; just as the fact that there is exactly one straight line passing through any two given distinct points. These invariants have been a central object of study in several fields, from their origins in theoretical physics (string theory) to algebraic and symplectic geometries. Computing such numbers for general spaces is a difficult task. For spaces with symmetries, gauged Gromov Witten theory has proven to be a far-reaching tool used to systematically understand the behavior of Gromov-Witten invariants as well as to compute them. One of the major accomplishments of gauged Gromov-Witten theory is the discovery of several explicit formulas for the invariants, which have been recently used to tackle open questions. This research project aims to advance understanding in this area. Due to the multidisciplinary nature of this field, new results will find direct applications in other areas.

One of the major accomplishments of gauged Gromov-Witten theory is the discovery of wall-crossing formulas, which in turn proved to be decisive in the proof of the so-called crepant conjecture. The present project undertakes work to further advance the research program in gauged Gromov-Witten theory for algebraic and symplectic quotients. The Principal Investigator and collaborators will work on an explicit computation of quantum K-theory of toric varieties and Grassmannians by means of the K-theoretic quantum Kirwan map, and extend wall crossing formulas to quantum K-theory. The Principal Investigator and collaborators will also study the moduli of parabolic gauged maps and the gauged Gromov-Witten theory for hypersurfaces. They will investigate relations to other constructions such as stable maps with p-fields and the Landau-Ginzburg A-model. The Principal Investigator will continue his joint work on a degeneration formula for Seidel elements and its relation to mirror symmetry and potential function of disc counting. He will work on a construction of invariants for toric orbifolds generalizing a Calabi quasi-morphism for projective spaces, and plans to use this to study non-displaceability. Finally, he will investigate the possibility of extending other equivariant tools into quantum cohomology and quantum K-theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the main outcomes of the project is that we were able to filalise a paper that was in preprint form for quite a long time. Our NSF-sponsored paper "Quantum Cohomology and Minimal Model Programs"  has been accepted for publication. We also managed to work on a preprint summarising work on quantum K-theory. More precisely, we have done progress on the construction and application of the quantum Kirwan map in the K-theoretic setting.  We also have ideas on how to compute invariants under Geometric Invariant Theory  transitions.  These results provide formulas that can be use to compute K-theoretic Gromov-Witten invariants. We discovered that the "Crepant invariance" does not follow as in the quantum cohomology case, but we need to use a symmetrised version of the theory. We are now working on the abelian-non abelian correspondence. Our first findings do not seem to agree with what we previously thought and we need to modified our original conjectured formulas. We will work on this this year.  

We also started a new (joint) project on the study of stratifications for gauged maps, which we hope to have ready in the next year or so. We expect that our work will provide a better unsderstanding of the geometry behind the moduli of gauged maps that will allow us to compute invariants in a much systematic way. 

We gave  five presentations on these subjects in seminars and colloquia.

The PI continued his involving in promoting mathematics to underepresented groups through his participation as an invited speaker at the MIT Roots programme for minority students. The PI worked as a reviwer for SACNAS (Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science).

The PI is ourganising a workshop in BIRS Oaxaca Mexico in 2019. 


Last Modified: 08/09/2019
Modified by: Eduardo Gonzalez

Our NSF-sponsored paper "Quantum Cohomology and Minimal Model Programs" has been accepted for publication. We also managed to work on a preprint summarising work on quantum K-theory. More precisely, we have done progress on the construction and application of the quantum Kirwan map in the K-theoretic setting. We also have ideas on how to compute invariants under Geometric Invariant Theory transitions. These results provide formulas that can be use to compute K-theoretic Gromov-Witten invariants. We discovered that the "Crepant invariance" does not follow as in the quantum cohomology case, but we need to use a symmetrised version of the theory. We are now working on the abelian-non abelian correspondence. Our first findings do not seem to agree with what we previously thought and we need to modified our original conjectured formulas. We will work on this this year. We also started a new (joint) project on the study of stratifications for gauged maps, which we hope to have ready in the next year or so. We expect that our work will provide a better unsderstanding of the geometry behind the moduli of gauged maps that will allow us to compute invariants in a much systematic way. We gave five presentations on these subjects in seminars and colloquia.
